caption: Figure 1: Lower and upper CVaRs and quantiles (β) of v(s') | s, a distribution.
description: This figure illustrates the concept of Conditional Value at Risk (CVaR) for a given distribution.  The x-axis represents the possible values of a random variable v(s') conditioned on state s and action a. The y-axis represents the probability density of v(s'). The curve shows the probability density function of v(s').  The shaded regions represent the lower and upper tails of the distribution, which correspond to CVaR⁻(s, a) and CVaR⁺(s, a), respectively.  The values β⁻(s, a) and β⁺(s, a) are the quantiles that define the boundaries of these tail regions.  E[v(s')|s,a] shows the expectation of v(s')|s,a.

caption: Figure 2: Results of our synthetic data experiments. We show results for our three estimators on all four A values, over our 10 experiment replications. Above: Box plot summarizing range of policy value estimates for each combination of estimator and A, with Horizontal red dashed lines showing the true worst-case policy values Vd1. Below: Table summarizing the corresponding MSE of these estimators for the true worst-case policy value, along with one standard deviation errors.
description: This figure presents the results of synthetic data experiments comparing three estimators for worst-case policy value: Q (RobustFQE), W (RobustMIL), and Orth (orthogonal).  The box plots show the distribution of estimated policy values for each estimator across four values of the sensitivity parameter A and 10 replications. The table provides the mean squared error (MSE) and standard deviation for each estimator and A value, relative to the true worst-case policy value. The results illustrate that the orthogonal estimator (Orth) generally performs better than the individual Q-function only and importance sampling only estimators.
